description: Kaiserstuhl Conservation Park is nestled amongst the Barossa Ranges and has panoramic views across to the Barossa Valley. Dusk and early mornings are the best time to be on the look out for wildlife; kangaroos feeding on the open grasslands, and the occasional echidna or possum may be seen foraging for food. There are two walking trails passing through a variety of landscapes including creeks, rocky outcrops, and areas of low forest, scrub and open grassland. The Wallowa Hike offers a comprehensive look at the park's main features, including rock formations and a scenic lookout, while the Stringybark Loop provides a brief look at the park's diverse flora and fauna.

location.description: Kaiserstuhl Conservation Park is located 12km south east of Tanunda in the Barossa Valley.

openingHours: The park is open from sunrise to sunset every day.

name: Sandy Creek Conservation Park
description: Sandy Creek Conservation Park is surrounded by farmland, vineyards and deep sand mining pits. Established on gently undulating sand dunes with occasional creeks, the park conserves some of the last remaining vegetation of the sandy soil lowlands of the Barossa Valley. Spring is the best time to view the wildflowers. Several walking trails through the native pine and pink gum allow you to explore the park. Look out for wildlife such as western grey kangaroos grazing on the grasslands at dawn and dusk. The richness and diversity of the park's birdlife makes it particularly significant for naturalists and birdwatchers. However, bird populations are in decline due to the changing habitat.

location.description: Sandy Creek Conservation Park is located 60km north east of Adelaide. Access is via Barossa Valley Highway.

openingHours: The park is open from sunrise to sunset every day.

name: Warren Conservation Park
description: Warren Conservation Park is characterised by steep country with views over forests, reservoirs, pastures and bushland above the spectacular Warren Gorge. The park is most colourful in spring when wattles, banksias, hakeas, heaths and eucalypts are in flower, but its native fauna and wild forests of stringybarks and long-leafed box are always worth a visit. The park has four challenging walking trails, including a section of the long distance and world famous Heysen Trail. The tracks are steep and difficult and should be used by experienced bushwalkers only. The relatively untouched nature is a haven for some of Australia's rarest animals and provides ideal opportunities for naturalists, birdwatchers and photographers.

location.description: Warren Conservation Park is located 60km north east of Adelaide. Walkers can access the park from Hale Conservation Park or from the Tower Track in Mt Crawford Forest.

openingHours: The park is open from sunrise to sunset every day.

name: Innes National Park
description: Innes National Park offers opportunities to enjoy camping, bushwalking, fishing and surfing. Discover the park's mining and maritime history by exploring the remnants of Inneston, once a booming gypsum-mining town, or go diving among the shipwrecks that lay off the coast of the park. You can even stay overnight in one of the restored miners cottages in the historic Inneston village. Purchase entry and camping permits from a self-registration station when you first enter the park. These are located adjacent to the park visitor centre, Innes Trading Post and Gym Beach Campground. To find out more information and to book accommodation at Inneston contact the Innes National Park Visitor Centre.

location.description: Innes National Park is located 300km west from Adelaide.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Troubridge Island
description: Troubridge Island Conservation Park is ideal for birdwatching. This fragile sand island is an important breeding area for birds and is home to a large colony of little penguins, black-faced cormorants and crested terns. Only accessible by boat, once you've reached the island, take in its beauty by fishing or swimming along the white sandy beaches. Hide away for a few nights in the original lighthouse keeper's cottage. The heritage-listed cottage accommodation has all the modern conveniences you need for an idyllic escape from city life. As the island protects nesting seabirds, the park is a prohibited area and is only accessible with a permit or with a guided tour.

location.description: Troubridge Island Conservation Park is located 63km west of Adelaide off the coast of Edithburgh. The island is only accessible by boat.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Lashmar Conservation Park
description: Lashmar Conservation Park, a favourite for beach lovers, adjoins the long sandy beach at Antechamber Bay. The park is an ideal location for swimming, fishing and birdwatching and is just a short drive from Cape Willoughby lightstation. Explore the park further by canoeing your way along the tranquil Chapman River which flows through the park and into the sea at Antechamber Bay. A scenic picnic area and campground are also available within the park.

location.description: Lashmar Conservation Park is located 40km south east of Penneshaw. Access is via Hog Bay Road.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Padthaway
description: Padthaway Conservation Park is ideal for birdwatchers. The park conserves a remnant block of native vegetation, which is dominated by South Australian blue gum, manna gum and stringybarks, making it a haven for native birdlife. Stroll along the walking trails, keep an eye out for orchids and marvel at the sights and sounds of birdlife or enjoy a picnic beneath the shade of the gums trees. You may even spot a koala enjoying its own picnic among the eucalypt branches.

location.description: Padthaway Conservation Park is located 254km south east of Adelaide off Riddoch Highway.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Coffin Bay National Park
description: Coffin Bay National Park conserves a diverse coastal landscapes ranging from high windswept cliffs and massive dunes to pounding surf beaches and sheltered sandy bays. At the southern end of the park, Yangie Bay offers an ideal place to paddle your canoe, enjoy a bush picnic or explore a coastal bushwalking trail and is 2WD accessible. The bays and coastline around the park are also great for boating, sailing, scuba diving and windsurfing. The stunning northern beaches of Coffin Bay National Park are only accessible by high-clearance 4WD. A favourite destination for anglers, birdwatchers and surfers, this remote and beautiful area offers several secluded camping areas with easy beach access.

location.description: Coffin Bay National Park is located 50km west of Port Lincoln. Access from Flinders Highway is via Coffin Bay Road.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Mokota Conservation Park
description: Mokota Conservation Park plays an important role in protecting native grassland and is one of the best, and largest, remaining examples of open tussock grassland in South Australia. Interpretive signs give you an insight into the unusually high quality grassland as you take a walk through the parkâ€™s trails. Mokota has 150 flora species surrounding it; some of the species are of conservation significance. The park also provides habitat for 28 animal species. The rare white spotted skipper butterfly is of particular interest and is listed as vulnerable. The park also provides habitat for the flinders worm lizard whose conservation status is listed as vulnerable at national and state levels.

location.description: Mokota Conservation Park is located 5km east of Mount Bryan (township) in the Clare Valley region.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Calpatanna Waterhole Conservation Park
description: Calpatanna Waterhole Conservation Park features a large salt lake and numerous saline flats where nearby swamp paperbarks can be found. Named after the Calpatanna waterhole which was an important water source for the traditional Aboriginal people of the area and early settlers, the park provides opportunities for bushwalking, nature study and camping. The 3,644 hectare park offers a diverse variety of habitats, ideal for native wildlife. A quiet walk through the bushland may reveal sightings of Mulga or Port Lincoln Parrots which often feed on the ground or move to nearby mallee trees when disturbed.

location.description: Calpatanna Waterhole Conservation Park is located 28km south east of Streaky Bay. Access is via Flinders Highway.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Mylor Conservation Park
description: Mylor Conservation Park and much of the region surrounding it has been largely cleared for residential and agricultural purposes. The park forms part of a mosaic of remnant bushland areas in the district which are linked by vegetation corridors on both public and private land. The park is used for a number of outdoor recreational activities, such as bushwalking or horse riding through the open woodland. Numerous bird species inhabit the area, making bird watching a popular activity for visitors. Keep an eye out for western grey kangaroos or eastern brown snakes that are often seen in the area. A section of the Heysen Trail runs through the park also.

location.description: Mylor Conservation Park is located in the Southern Mount Lofty Ranges, 15km south east of Adelaide.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Telowie Gorge Conservation Park
description: Telowie Gorge Conservation Park is home to a colony of yellow-footed rock-wallabies and features some of the most dramatic scenery in the Southern Flinders Ranges. Animal watching, bushwalking and camping are popular ways to enjoy the park's wilderness setting. The gorge and its diverse landforms have been created by Telowie Creek, which over time has cut a deep gorge through the range. Today, the gorge creates a rich variety of habitats for animals and plants from both the southern temperate and arid regions. During winter, Telowie Creek flows from the gorge onto the plains.

location.description: Telowie Gorge Conservation Park is located 25km north east of Port Pirie (45 min); 248km north of Adelaide. Access is via Highway 1.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Cleland Wildlife Park
description: Cleland Wildlife Park, just twenty minutes drive from the Adelaide city centre is where you can meet some of South Australia's most iconic inhabitants and cuddle a koala! Wander at your leisure among kangaroos, wallabies, emus and waterfowl. Many of the animals in the park are free to roam the open spaces. The animals are accustomed to people, meaning you can pat and feed them. The park has been a major tourist attraction in South Australia since 1967. Nestled within the natural bush setting of Cleland Conservation Park and adjacent to Mount Lofty Summit, the park provides 35 hectares of open bushland habitat where visitors can interact with Australian wildlife.

location.description: Cleland Wildlife Park is only 20 minutes from the Adelaide city centre. Just take the South Eastern Freeway to the Crafers exit, then follow Summit Road to the Cleland turn off.

openingHours: 9.30am - 5pm daily (except Christmas Day). No entry after 4.30pm. Aviaries close at 4.30pm.

name: Naracoorte Caves National Park
description: Naracoorte Caves National Park is South Australia's only World Heritage site. The site was officially recognised in 1994 because of the importance of the fossils in the caves. The park is home to over 100 known fossil deposits, preserving the bones of megafauna that became extinct roughly 60,000 years ago. Naracoorte Caves preserves Australia's most complete fossil record for the past 500,000 years. The World Heritage trail is a popular 1.3 kilometre track that stretches from the Wonambi Fossil Centre to the Victoria Fossil Cave. The walk features informative milestones that highlight the World Heritage features of the park, making it popular with those interested in the park's ancient history.

location.description: Naracoorte Caves National Park is located on Hynam-Caves Road, 10km south of the main township of Naracoorte.

name: Seal Bay Conservation Park
description: Seal Bay Conservation Park is a major tourist destination welcoming around 110,000 visitors a year. We provide guided tours along Seal Bay beach where you can walk amongst the resident colony of Australian sea lions. Or you can choose to walk the boardwalk to view the sea lions from afar. As well as tours, there are picnic and barbecue areas at the Bales Bay Picnic Area. There is a short walk from the picnic grounds to a lookout which offers excellent views of Cape Gantheaume and the wilderness area. A short drive takes you to beautiful Bales Beach; an opportunity to relax and enjoy the surrounds in an unspoilt location.

location.description: Seal Bay is on Seal Bay Road, just off South Coast Road on Kangaroo Island.

openingHours: 9am - 5pm daily (except Christmas Day). 9am - 6pm in Dec and Jan.

name: Ngaut Ngaut Conservation Park
description: Book a tour and explore this culturally and historically significant conservation park with an experienced guide from the Mannum Aboriginal Community Association.

location.description: Ngaut Ngaut Conservation Park is located along the west side of the River Murray approximately 12 kms south of Swan Reach and close to the Nildottie Township. It is approximately 170km north of Adelaide. You can access the park by either the Walker Flat-Mannum Road or the Swan Reach-Walker Flat Road, via Hunter Road and Purnong Road. Both require crossing via a ferry if you are coming from the Mannum side of the River.

openingHours: In recognition of the cultural significance of this park we request that you contact the Mannum Aboriginal Community Association prior to planning a visit to the park.

name: Cobbler Creek Recreation Park
description: Cobbler Creek Recreation Park is surrounded by woodlands and open grasslands; here you can discover the ruins of the area's first European farms. There are also two walking trails to choose from: the 6.8km Porosa Walkabout Loop walk where you can visit several natural and cultural sites the Babbler Loop Trail, a shorter walk which climbs to a stunning view across the Adelaide plains. As you walk through the park, watch out for birds of prey such as the Australian kestrel, Red-rumped parrots, crested pigeons, red wattlebirds and lorikeets. You can walk your dog in this park along designated walking trails, provided it remains under your control on a lead.

location.description: Cobbler Creek Recreation Park is located 19km north of Adelaide. Access is via Bridge Road, The Grove Way and Green Valley Drive.

openingHours: The park is open from sunrise to sunset every day.

name: Anstey Hill Recreation Park
description: Anstey Hill Recreation Park provides an insight into the area's history and conserves rare vegetation once widespread throughout the Adelaide Plains and Mount Lofty Ranges. Be sure to visit in spring when the wildflowers and orchids are in bloom over the steep slopes. You can walk your dog in this park provided it remains under your control on a lead. The park's steep gullies, creek lines and views of Adelaide city provide a spectacular backdrop for bushwalkers, birdwatchers, photographers and painters to enjoy. There are also 145 species of native birds to look out for. The extensive network of walking trails showcase the park's variety of plant species and habitats.

location.description: Anstey Hill Recreation Park is located 16km north east of Adelaide. Access is via Perseverance Road.

openingHours: The park is open from sunrise to sunset every day.

name: Angove Conservation Park
description: Angove Conservation Park conserves one of the last remaining stands of remnant Drooping Sheoak and Southern Cypress Pine open woodlands within the Adelaide foothills. The park contains 142 native plant species and provides specialised habitat for a small number of animals that require dense vegetation to survive. Several species of reptiles can also be found, along with mammals such as ringtail and brush-tailed possums, bats and 74 species of birds. The park has a dedicated Friends of Parks volunteer group who contribute to the management of the park by maintaining walking trails and fire breaks, conducting weed control projects and educating the public about the park.

location.description: Angove Conservation Park is located 18km north east from Adelaide. Access is via Bowen Road.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Coorong National Park
description: Coorong National Park protects a string of saltwater lagoons and the wetlands are of enormous cultural significance to the Ngarrindjeri people, with ancient mounds of discarded shells revealing archaeological evidence of Aboriginal campsites over thousands of years. The distinctive landscape is an important breeding area for the Australian pelican and is a refuge for numerous species of migratory birds. The park can be explored by the various walking trails, paddling along waterways by kayak, or four-wheel driving along designated tracks and the beach. The diverse number of birds that visit the area also provides ideal birdwatching and photographic opportunities. Scenic campgrounds are located on both sides of the lagoon.

location.description: The Coorong National Park is located south east of Adelaide. The southern part of the park is accessible via Goolwa, Meningie and Salt Creek off Highway 1. If you are arriving from the south, enter the park via Kingston.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Martindale Hall Conservation Park
description: Martindale Hall Conservation Park offers a fascinating insight into the lives of South Australia's wealthy gentry during the late 1800s to early 1900s.

location.description: Martindale Hall Conservation Park is located 130km north of Adelaide in the Clare Valley region. Access is via Main North Road.

openingHours: Martindale Hall is open from 11am to 4pm Wednesday to Monday, closed Tuesday for cleaning. During school holidays, Martindale Hall is open 7 days from 11am to 4pm, except Good Friday and Christmas Day.

name: Kyeema Conservation Park
description: Kyeema Conservation Park was once mined for alluvial gold for several years until it was abandoned in 1890. A few years later some of the area was cleared for pine plantations before being used as a labour prison reserve. Since the 1983 Ash Wednesday fires, the Friends of Kyeema Conservation Park have been revegetating cleared areas of the park. Today, Kyeema Conservation Park's native vegetation can be enjoyed along a number of walking trails, including the Heysen Trail which runs through the park. The combination of messmate stringybark, pink gum, cup gum and candlebark gum provide habitat for a diverse range of wildlife and more than 70 species of birds.

location.description: Kyeema Conservation Park is located 60km south of Adelaide. Access is via Woodgate Hill Road.

openingHours: Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: Kelly Hill Conservation Park
description: Kelly Hill Conservation Park, located in the south-west of Kangaroo Island, has an impressive limestone cave system to explore. Guided tours allow you to walk amidst ornate cave formations, admire the array of stalactite, stalagmite, shawl, helictite and column formations and discover how the caves are formed. For the more adventurous, join an experienced guide on an Adventure Caving Tour where, equipped with a helmet and headlamp, you can crawl your way through an underground maze of smaller caverns. Above ground, choose from one of the short walking trails or spend a day hiking to Hanson Bay which passes by a landscape of freshwater lagoons, mallee woodlands and coastal dunes.

location.description: Kelly Hill Conservation Park is located 90km south west of Kingscote. Access via South Coast Road.

openingHours: Day visitors to Kelly Hill Conservation Park are requested to leave the park by sunset. Kelly Hill Caves Visitor Centre is open 10.15am-4.30pm daily (except Christmas Day. Find information on tour times for Kelly Hill Caves on http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/parks/Find_a_Park/Browse_by_region/Kangaroo_Island/Kelly_Hill/tour-times

name: Cape Willoughby Conservation Park
description: Cape Willoughby Conservation Park is home to South Australia's first lighthouse. To discover more about the areas role in coastal shipping, colonial trading and passenger transport, you can: join a guided tour and enjoy spectacular views across Backstairs Passage while looking out for large schools of salmon or pods of whales; gain an insight into the working and living conditions of the early lightkeepers along the Cape Willoughby Lightstation heritage hike; visit the Cape Willoughby park visitor centre which features a museum with a photograph collection, as well as equipment that was once used at the site; stay in one of the delightful heritage-listed lightkeepers cottages, see http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/parks/Find_a_Park/Browse_by_region/Kangaroo_Island/Cape_Willoughby/Accommodation

location.description: Cape Willoughby Conservation Park is located 27km south east of Penneshaw. Access is via Cape Willoughby Road.

openingHours: Open 7 days a week. Cape Willoughby Conservation Park Visitor Centre is open 9am-3.30pm daily (except Christmas Day). Daily tour times: 11.30am, 12.30pm and 2.00pm.

name: Cape Borda Lightstation
description: Cape Borda Lightstation is perched on cliffs overlooking Investigator Strait.

location.description: Cape Borda Lighstation is located in Flinders Chase National Park 110km west of Kingscote, Kangaroo Island.

openingHours: Day visitors to Flinders Chase National Park are requested to leave the park by sunset. The Flinders Chase Visitor Centre is open 9am-5pm daily (except Christmas Day). Daily tour times: 11.00, 12.30 pm and 2.00pm.
